Hi All,
   If some of the comments made could be fused and edited the 
tekk=
otsu in tsuba may be explained as to why they appear or not.
   When tsuba =
were in their infancy on the new curved single edged 
sword they were made =
by the smiths who made the swords. It makes no 
sense that separate steels =
would be used, so the tamahagane and old 
steels being reused were the base=
 metals used in the tsuba 
manufacture. this would cause the same character=
istics found in the 
blades to appear in the tsuba. Inclusions, layers, and=
 
nonhomogeneity in the steel itself. In the art sense this would be 
the p=
rimitivist stage where form came before function. The times 
were constant =
warfare and all parts must be robust.
   Now come the times of peace and fo=
r the most part form supplants 
function. Soft iron is a good plate for car=
ving and inlay and soft 
metals become more and more common. No more tekkot=
su for the most 
part except for the few schools that continue the traditio=
n of 
worked steel.
    Shinshinto times bring the revival of the old ways.=
 What 
appeared on old tsuba was now a favourable thing to copy including 
=
using steel again and emphasising attributes such as tekkotsu. 
Appreciatio=
n of functional aspects were now artistically 
appreciated. What was functi=
onal had now become raised to the 
highest form. This happened in the Chano=
yu, Kodo and was almost 
decadent. I'll leave that argument for another day=
. John
